quiz.name: Module 8: Yield and Yield Spread Measures for Floating-Rate Instruments
quiz.subtopic: Module 8: Yield and Yield Spread Measures for Floating-Rate Instruments

answerFeedback.59533b4b-b660-416b-84fd-9fa3ff803366: Incorrect because money market instruments having different times-to-maturity have different periodicities for the annual rate.
answerFeedback.de32f99d-dc20-4001-9284-59299b3580fd: Incorrect because bond yields-to-maturity are annualized and compounded. Yield measures in the money market are annualized but not compounded.
answerFeedback.ec52e7b5-7634-4b68-96cb-21becca23d2e: Correct because the rate of return on a money market instrument is stated on a simple interest basis.

choices.itemBody: C. stated on a simple interest basis.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08935
entry.itemBody: For a floating-rate note, the specified yield spread over the reference rate best defines the:

answerFeedback.1871d6af-5835-444a-a932-b9c184ab4dce: Incorrect because a specified yield spread is added to, or subtracted from, the reference rate which results in the coupon. For example, the floater might reset its interest rate quarterly at the reference rate plus 0.50%. This is not the quoted margin, it is the reference rate plus the quoted margin.
answerFeedback.593b542a-3706-4c08-bf64-74a8396859b3: Incorrect because the required margin is the yield spread over, or under, the reference rate such that the FRN is priced at par value on a rate reset date. Changes in the required margin usually come from changes in the issuer's credit risk. The required margin is not specified but changes based on market forces.
answerFeedback.914b9172-ccd9-4599-9211-86288bb88059: Correct because this specified yield spread over the reference rate is called the quoted margin on the FRN. The role of the quoted margin is to compensate the investor for the difference in the credit risk of the issuer and that implied by the reference rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Groenning-18
entry.itemBody:
A commercial paper has the following characteristics:

Redemption value $5,000,000
Interest earned $140,500
Days to maturity 160

For a 365-day year, the discount rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.9086e9e7-ce56-4e57-9ad1-cdf6424565b2:
Incorrect because this is the add-on rate. AOR = Year/Days × ((FV – PV)/PV) 

AOR = (365/160) × (140,500/(5,000,000 – 140,500)) = 0.0660 ≈ 6.6%.
answerFeedback.97c7590f-887f-4125-bab3-ba31750d2fe9:
Incorrect because candidates confuse the redemption value with the present value and thereby add the interest earned to the redemption value as part of the calculation.

DR ≠ (365/160) × (140,500/(5,000,000 + 140,500)) = 0.0624 ≈ 6.2%.
answerFeedback.ec6996db-fa54-4a99-a6f2-b8fbed12e6b6:
Correct because the discount rate, DR = (Year/Days) × ((FV – PV)/FV), where Year = number of days in the year, Days = number of days between settlement and maturity, FV = future value paid at maturity/face value of the money market instrument, PV = present value/price of the money market instrument, and FV – PV, is the interest earned.

DR = (365/160) × (140,500/5,000,000) = 0.0641 ≈ 6.4%.

entry.title: ITEM_Copy of CFA-L1-04317
entry.itemBody: A floating-rate note makes semiannual interest payments and has a coupon rate equal to the six-month market reference rate plus 45 basis points. The interest payments are made in June and December. If the six-month market reference rate was 1.95% in June and 2.25% in December of the same year, the coupon rate paid in December of that year was closest to:

answerFeedback.2f54fcbf-8205-4364-b5d5-3a945c0a7054: Incorrect because the 45 bps margin is added to the average of the June and December six-month market reference rates = (2.25% + 1.95%) / 2 + 0.45% = 2.55%.
answerFeedback.71b94143-d9d0-44db-b236-5eb2df27700b: Correct because the applicable interest rate in December is the six-month market reference rate in June plus the 45 basis point margin = 1.95% + 0.45% = 2.40%.
answerFeedback.d1164b25-19cf-4c4a-a655-e763ed39db3b: Incorrect because the 45 bps margin is added to the market reference rate in December = 2.25% + 0.45% = 2.70%.

entry.title: CFA2438-R-s03-Q9

feedback.neutral:
C is correct.

Using the information provided, the periodic PMT is equal to

( M R R + Q M ) × F V m = ( − 0.055 + 0.016 ) × 100 4 = 0.2625.

Using the RATE function in Microsoft Excel, Google Sheets, or a financial calculator and using PV = –101.20, FV = 100, PMT =0.275, and N = 8, we solve for the discount rate per period of 0.11175%. The discount margin can then be estimated by solving for DM:

r = M R R + D M m .
0.0011175 = − 0.0055 + D M 4 .
D M = 0.9970%.

The estimated discount margin is 99.7 bps.

entry.itemBody: A two-year floating-rate note issued by a French corporation pays the three-month MRR of –0.55% plus 160 bps. The floater is priced at 101.20 per 100 of par value. Assuming the 30/360 day-count convention and 90 days per period and a flat yield curve, the discount margin for the floater is closest to:

entry.title: CFA2438-R-s03-Q10

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. The required margin is the yield spread over or under a reference rate, reflecting the credit risk of an issuer. Changes in the required margin typically come from a change in the issuer’s credit risk.

A and C are incorrect. Both risks, as “top-down” or macroeconomic risks, would be reflected in changes in the MRR, not in a spread such as the required margin.

entry.itemBody: Changes in the required margin for a floater usually come from:

choices.itemBody: A. shifts in the yield curve.
C. increases or decrease in inflation.

entry.body:
A fixed-income portfolio manager is looking to value a one-year US dollar–denominated floating-rate note that has quarterly payments based on 90-day MRR plus 80 bps. Assume the following information:

  • 90-Day MRR: 2.5%

  • Quoted Margin: 80 bps

  • Discount Margin: 100 bps

  • Face Value: USD100
entry.title: Vignette
CFA2438-R-s03-Q11

feedback.neutral: B is correct. This FRN is priced at a discount, because the quoted margin is less than the discount (required) margin.

entry.itemBody: Without doing any calculation, this floating-rate note is priced at:

entry.title: CFA2438-R-s03-Q12

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. The FRN is priced at 99.804 per 100 of par value. Using the information provided, the periodic PMT is equal to

( M R R + Q M ) × F V m = ( 0.025 + 0.008 ) × 100 4 = 0.825.

The assumed discount rate per period is equal to 0.875%.

r = M R R + D M m .
r = 0.025 + 0.01 4 .
r = 0.00875.

To value this FRN, take the present value of each cash flow using the discount rate per period. The FRN is priced at 99.804 per 100 of par value.

P V = 0.825 ( 1 + 0.00875 ) 1 + 0.825 ( 1 + 0.00875 ) 2 + 0.825 ( 1 + 0.00875 ) 3 + 100.825 ( 1 + 0.00875 ) 4 .
P V = 99.804.

entry.itemBody: The price of the FRN is closest to:

entry.title: CFA2438-R-s03-Q13

feedback.neutral:
C is correct. The bond equivalent yield is closest to 0.56%.

The present value of the banker’s certificate of deposit is calculated as follows:

P V = F V × ( 1 − Days Year × D R ) .
P V = 100 × ( 1 − 90 360 × 0.0055 ) .
P V = 99.865.

The bond equivalent yield (AOR using a 365-day year) is calculated to be approximately 0.56%:

A O R = Year Days × F V − P V P V .
A O R = 365 90 × 100 − 99.8625 99.8625 .
A O R = 0.0056.

entry.itemBody: The bond equivalent yield of a 90-day European bank certificate of deposit quoted at a discount rate of 0.55% for a 360-day year is closest to:

entry.title: CFA2438-R-s03-Q14

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. The discount rate is closest to 0.2011.

D R = Year Days × ( F V − P V ) F V .
D R = 366 91 × ( 2 , 000 , 000 − 1 , 900 , 000 ) 2 , 000 , 000 .
D R = 0.2011.

entry.itemBody: A 91-day UK gilt (Treasury bill) has a face value of GBP2 million, a discount rate of 0.25%, and a price of GBP1.9 million. If a year has 366 days, the discount rate for the UK gilt is closest to:

entry.title: CFA2438-R-s03-Q15

feedback.neutral:
For a money market instrument, the discount rate is calculated as

D R = Year Days × ( F V − P V ) F V .

The denominator for the second term is FV, not PV. In theory, an interest rate is the amount earned divided by the investment amount (PV), not the maturity value (FV), which includes the earnings. So long as DR is greater than zero, FV will be higher than PV. Therefore, by design, a money market discount rate understates the rate of return to the investor, and it understates the cost of borrowed funds to the issuer.

entry.itemBody: Explain why a money market discount rate greater than zero understates the rate of return to an investor and understates the cost of borrowed funds for the issuer.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607048
entry.itemBody: If the yield to maturity on an annual-pay bond is 7.75%, the semiannual bond-equivalent yield is closest to:

answerFeedback.75bf005b-054b-4d83-9488-d29fc1a6d8df: Incorrect. The semiannual bond-equivalent yield is incorrectly calculated as [(1 + 0.0775)2 – 1]/2 = 0.0805 or 8.05%.
answerFeedback.e2916a07-d174-4c9e-9b7f-48fec67fe2ba: Correct. The most common periodicity for US dollar-denominated bond yields is two because most bonds in the US dollar market make semiannual coupon payments. An annual rate having a periodicity of two is known as a semiannual bond basis yield, or semiannual bond equivalent yield. Therefore, a semiannual bond basis yield is the yield per semiannual period times two. For this example, we need to take the YTM of the annual coupon bond, which is an effective annual rate, and convert it to a semiannual bond equivalent yield: 2 × (1.07750.5 – 1) = 0.07605 or 7.61%.
answerFeedback.f8312f94-ba21-4a78-b101-35227c92bfb1: Incorrect. The semiannual bond-equivalent yield is incorrectly calculated as [1 + (0.0775/2)]2 – 1 = 0.079 or 7.90%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607058
entry.itemBody: DMT Corp. issued a five-year floating-rate note (FRN) that pays a quarterly coupon of three-month market reference rate (MRR) plus 125 bps. The FRN is priced at 96 per 100 of par value. Assuming a 30/360-day count convention, evenly spaced periods, and constant three-month market reference rate (MRR) of 5%, the discount margin for the FRN is closest to:

answerFeedback.122e777b-2929-48c3-a725-9dd4b1929f87: Incorrect because it uses the quarterly discount rate 1.8025% as the solution, i.e., 180 bps.
answerFeedback.587dcc93-7e1d-4539-89cb-3c52464efd58: Incorrect because it uses the price discount of 100% – 96% = 4%, i.e., 400 bps.
answerFeedback.f5a48852-a73a-40f1-80ce-93c24b8319dc:
Correct because the interest payment each period per 100 of par value is

( Index+QM )×FV m = ( 0.05+0.0125 )×100 4 =1.5625

Where index is the market reference rate

The discount margin can be estimated by solving for DM in the equation

96= 1.5625 ( 1+ 0.05+DM 4 ) 1 + 1.5625 ( 1+ 0.05+DM 4 ) 2 +⋯+ 1.5625 ( 1+ 0.05+DM 4 ) 20

The solution for the discount rate, r = (0.05 + DM)/4 is 1.8025%. Therefore, DM = 2.21% or 221 bps.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607059
entry.itemBody:
Which of the following 90-day money market instruments most likely offers the investor the highest rate of return?

Money Market Instrument Quoted Rate Quotation Basis Day Convention
Instrument A 5.78% 360 Discount rate
Instrument B 5.80% 365 Discount rate
Instrument C 5.96% 365 Add-on rate

answerFeedback.76eca831-04d3-42ec-a52e-11f5755bda48:
Incorrect. To calculate the bond equivalent yield: FV = 100, Days = 90, Year = 360, DR = 0.0578.

PV = 100 × [1 – (90/360) × 0.0578] = 98.555

AOR = (365/90) × [(100 – 98.555)/98.555] = 5.946%
answerFeedback.8d109f2b-4482-4962-ba45-681b8409b57c:
Incorrect. To calculate the bond equivalent yield: FV = 100, Days = 90, Year = 365, DR = 0.058.

PV = 100 × [1 – (90/365) × 0.058] = 98.570

AOR = (365/90) × [(100 – 98.570)/98.5705] = 5.883%
answerFeedback.9418cfd4-ed40-46a2-ac2b-a8d4f6eb1470: Correct. Instrument C provides a bond equivalent yield of 5.96%, compared with 5.946% for Instrument A and 5.883% for Instrument B.
